column2: Dirty Money is money earned by illegitimate means. It can be converted to wealth by laundering. Dirty Money is lost and added to your score on succession.

After decades of lobbying by diverse Protestant Temperance Unions, the sale, production and importation of alcoholic beverages was banned under the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution beginning on January 17th, 1920. Designed to reduce alcoholism and corruption across the country, the Amendment proved almost impossible to enforce and ended up increasing violent crime and playing a major role in the rise of various criminal gangs.

Giuseppe "the Clutch Hand" Morello was the first boss of the Morello Crime Family, the oldest of the Five Families. As a Sicilian-born immigrant he controlled much of New York's Italian-American territory throughout the 1900s. After his imprisonment in 1909, his gang was led by various close relatives and emerged victorious from the Mafia-Camorra War of 1915-1917. In 1920, Morello found himself in a precarious situation after being released from prison. Historically, he would struggle to hold on to control and soon go on to become Consigliere to Giuseppe Masseria who led the Family until the Castellammarese War.

With a score of $SCORE$ you$FAILED$ beat the Genovese crime family, descended from Robert the Strong who was a power figure during the reign of Charles the Bald. His descendants would be Kings of France in 1066. Although by 1322 the main line would die out, cadet branches still ruled in 1337 as Kings of France, Portugal, Naples, Hungary and Navarre. Cadet branches would also hold the Duchies of Brittany, Burgundy, Bourbon, Provence and Achaea. One further cadet branch would hold the dignity of Emperor as Latin Emperors of Constantinople. Truly the greatest dynasty of medieval Europe.

column2: With a score of $SCORE$ you$FAILED$ beat the Gambino crime family. On the face of it, things were not looking very good for the Habsburg family in 1066. As minor Swiss counts, their status inside the Empire was fairly negligible compared to great territorial magnates of 11th century Germany. A policy of tactical marriages saw the family lands expand steadily, and it was during the chaos that gripped the Empire in the late 13h and early 14th century that the family were elected to the office of Holy Roman Empire. Although unable to hold the office they were able to use this a springboard to secure the Duchy of Austria for the dynasty. With this power base, the family would go on to dominate the politics of Central Europe until 1918.

column2: With a score of $SCORE$ you$FAILED$ beat House de Montfort, who were small scale land holders in France. Through marriage and service the family gained estates in both Normandy and England. It was under the zealous but cruel Simon de Montfort the Elder that the family ascended. The family reached the height of its power through his son Simon de Montfort the Younger, who became de facto ruler of England. However, all this would prove fleeting and by 1337 the family would have lost it all and gone extinct in the male line.
